title: Early symptoms of dengue
question_variants: What are early signs of dengue?
How will I know if I have dengue?
Early symptoms of dengue fever?
canonical_answer: Early symptoms typically appear 4–7 days after an infected mosquito bite and often include sudden high fever, severe headache, pain behind the eyes, muscle and joint pain, and sometimes a skin rash. Symptoms overlap with other infections; laboratory testing confirms diagnosis.

title: Dengue rash description
question_variants: Does dengue cause a rash?
What does dengue rash look like?
How is the rash in dengue?
canonical_answer: A rash may appear 2–5 days after fever onset and can be flushed or measles-like. Rash varies between individuals and is not specific to dengue—use other symptoms and testing to confirm.

title: When to test for dengue
question_variants: When should I get tested for dengue?
Which test detects dengue early?
canonical_answer: Common tests include NS1 antigen and PCR early in illness (first week) and IgM/IgG serology later. Test choice depends on days since symptom onset; consult a clinician for appropriate testing.

title: Treatment approach for dengue
question_variants: How is dengue treated?
What should I do if I have dengue?
canonical_answer: Most dengue infections are managed with supportive care: rest, adequate fluids, and paracetamol for fever and pain. Avoid NSAIDs and aspirin because they increase bleeding risk. Seek medical care for warning signs or worsening symptoms.

title: Warning signs of severe dengue
question_variants: What are danger signs of dengue?
When to go to hospital for dengue?
canonical_answer: Warning signs that need immediate medical attention include severe abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, bleeding from any site, rapid breathing, lethargy, sudden weakness, and fainting—these may signal severe dengue.

title: Fluid management in dengue
question_variants: How much liquid should a dengue patient drink?
Is hydration important in dengue?
canonical_answer: Maintaining adequate hydration is crucial. Adults should take frequent small amounts of oral fluids or oral rehydration solution. Clinicians may provide IV fluids in severe cases; do not self-administer large IV volumes.

title: Safe medicines for dengue
question_variants: Which painkillers are safe in dengue?
Can I take ibuprofen for dengue?
canonical_answer: Use paracetamol (acetaminophen) for fever and pain. Avoid NSAIDs such as ibuprofen, naproxen, and aspirin because they increase bleeding risk. Follow dosing guidance and consult a clinician for children and those with other health conditions.

title: Dengue in children
question_variants: How is dengue different in children?
My child has fever — is it dengue?
canonical_answer: Children can present with similar symptoms but may deteriorate faster. Watch for lethargy, persistent vomiting, bleeding, or difficulty breathing—seek immediate care for these signs. Use pediatric dosing and avoid NSAIDs/aspirin.

title: Dengue during pregnancy
question_variants: Can dengue harm pregnancy?
Pregnant and suspect dengue — what to do?
canonical_answer: Dengue during pregnancy requires clinical evaluation because it can affect the mother and fetus. Pregnant individuals with suspected dengue should seek prompt medical care; management depends on gestational age and clinical status.

title: Dengue serotypes and reinfection
question_variants: Can you get dengue more than once?
What happens if I get dengue again?
canonical_answer: There are four dengue virus serotypes (DENV-1 to DENV-4). Infection with one serotype typically gives lasting protection against that type but not others; subsequent infections with different serotypes may increase risk of severe disease.

title: When to hospitalize for dengue
question_variants: Will I need admission for dengue?
Which dengue patients go to hospital?
canonical_answer: Hospitalization is necessary for those with warning signs, severe bleeding, shock, inability to tolerate oral fluids, or organ dysfunction. Hospital care provides close monitoring and IV fluid management.

title: Typical dengue illness timeline
question_variants: How long does dengue last?
What is the recovery time for dengue?
canonical_answer: Dengue illness commonly has three phases: febrile (2–7 days), critical (around days 3–7 when complications may appear), and recovery (days to weeks). Many recover after the critical phase; fatigue may linger for weeks.

title: Preventing mosquito bites
question_variants: How to avoid mosquito bites?
Ways to protect from dengue mosquitoes?
canonical_answer: Use window/door screens, bed nets for infants, long clothing, and recommended insect repellents. Stay in screened or air-conditioned places when possible and reduce outdoor exposure during peak mosquito activity.

title: Eliminating mosquito breeding sites
question_variants: How do I stop mosquitoes breeding at home?
Remove standing water to prevent dengue?
canonical_answer: Empty or cover containers that hold water (flower pots, buckets, tyres), clean gutters, cover water storage, and organize community clean-ups to reduce Aedes breeding sites.

title: Aedes mosquito biting times
question_variants: When do dengue mosquitoes bite?
Are dengue mosquitoes active at night?
canonical_answer: Aedes mosquitoes bite mainly during daytime, especially early morning and late afternoon. Use daytime protective measures—bed nets alone are not sufficient against daytime-biting mosquitoes.

title: Reporting dengue cases
question_variants: Should I report dengue cases?
How to notify health authorities about dengue?
canonical_answer: Reporting suspected or confirmed dengue cases to local public health agencies helps trigger control measures. Health facilities commonly report cases; contact your local public health office for procedures.

title: Travel advice for dengue
question_variants: How to avoid dengue when traveling?
Is dengue common at my destination?
canonical_answer: Before travel, check local dengue risk and practice mosquito avoidance. Seek medical attention for fever after travel. Pregnant travelers should obtain specific medical advice before travel.

title: Dengue vaccine basics
question_variants: Is there a dengue vaccine?
Can I get vaccinated against dengue?
canonical_answer: Dengue vaccines exist but recommendations vary by country, age, and prior infection. Vaccine use is guided by national authorities; consult local health services about eligibility and timing.

title: Difference between dengue and flu
question_variants: How is dengue different from the flu?
Dengue vs influenza symptoms?
canonical_answer: Both can cause fever, headache, and body aches. Dengue often causes severe joint/muscle pain and pain behind the eyes and may be associated with bleeding or plasma leakage; laboratory tests distinguish them.

title: Myth: coconut water cures dengue
question_variants: Does coconut water cure dengue?
Can home remedies cure dengue?
canonical_answer: No food or herb cures dengue. Hydration and rest can help relieve symptoms, but medical monitoring is essential. Home remedies may provide comfort but are not replacements for medical care when warning signs occur.

title: What is severe dengue?
question_variants: What does severe dengue mean?
How severe dengue presents?
canonical_answer: Severe dengue involves plasma leakage leading to shock, severe bleeding, or organ impairment and requires urgent hospital-based management with fluid resuscitation and close monitoring.

title: NS1 antigen testing window
question_variants: When is NS1 test positive?
How early can NS1 detect dengue?
canonical_answer: NS1 antigen and PCR are most useful in the early phase (first 5–7 days). Sensitivity depends on timing and test quality; negative early tests may need repeat testing or different assays.

title: Breastfeeding and dengue
question_variants: Can I breastfeed if I have dengue?
Is it safe to breastfeed with dengue?
canonical_answer: Breastfeeding is generally recommended; benefits typically outweigh risks. Practice mosquito avoidance to protect the infant and consult healthcare providers for individualized advice.

title: Children warning signs
question_variants: What danger signs in children with dengue?
When to take a child to hospital for dengue?
canonical_answer: Urgent signs in children include persistent vomiting, severe abdominal pain, bleeding, lethargy, difficulty breathing, or signs of dehydration—seek immediate evaluation if these occur.

title: Home care for mild dengue
question_variants: How do I care for dengue at home?
Home treatments for dengue?
canonical_answer: For mild dengue: rest, keep hydrated, use paracetamol for fever/pain, monitor for warning signs, and follow healthcare advice. Avoid NSAIDs and aspirin. Seek care if symptoms worsen.

title: Return to work after dengue
question_variants: When can I go back to work after dengue?
Is it safe to return to school after dengue?
canonical_answer: Return when clinically well and afebrile, and follow local health guidance. Fatigue may persist; gradual return to activities may be advisable. For children, confirm with their healthcare provider or school if required.

title: Blood donation after dengue
question_variants: When can I donate blood after dengue?
Is dengue safe for blood donors?
canonical_answer: Blood donation policies vary; donors are typically deferred for a period after dengue infection. Check with local blood services for specific deferral intervals.

title: Mosquito repellents guidance
question_variants: Which mosquito repellent should I use?
What repellents work against dengue mosquitoes?
canonical_answer: Use WHO/CDC-recommended repellents (DEET, picaridin, IR3535, or oil of lemon eucalyptus) as directed. Apply on exposed skin and follow label instructions, including for children.

title: Household insecticide role
question_variants: Can I spray insecticide at home for dengue?
Are household sprays effective?
canonical_answer: Household insecticides can reduce adult mosquitoes temporarily but are not a substitute for eliminating breeding sites. Follow product instructions and public health advice for safe use.

title: How dengue spreads
question_variants: How is dengue transmitted?
Can dengue spread person-to-person?
canonical_answer: Dengue is transmitted by infected Aedes mosquitoes; it is not spread by casual person-to-person contact. Preventing mosquito bites reduces transmission risk.

title: After a mosquito bite
question_variants: I was bitten—what should I do?
After mosquito bite, how to know if dengue?
canonical_answer: One mosquito bite does not mean dengue; monitor for symptoms for up to 14 days. If fever or severe symptoms occur, seek medical evaluation and testing.

title: Dengue vs chikungunya
question_variants: Dengue vs chikungunya — what's different?
How to tell dengue from chikungunya?
canonical_answer: Both are mosquito-borne. Chikungunya often causes more severe joint pain; laboratory tests distinguish them. Clinical overlap exists; testing helps accurate diagnosis.

title: Monitoring platelets in dengue
question_variants: Why check platelets in dengue?
Is low platelets dangerous in dengue?
canonical_answer: Platelet counts may fall in dengue; clinicians monitor platelets along with clinical signs of bleeding or plasma leakage. Decisions are based on trends and overall clinical picture.

title: Isolation and dengue
question_variants: Should I isolate if I have dengue?
Can I go outside with dengue?
canonical_answer: Strict isolation is not required because dengue is not spread person-to-person. However, protect yourself from mosquitoes to avoid onward transmission and practice mosquito avoidance measures.

title: Community outbreak control
question_variants: How to stop dengue outbreaks?
Community measures for dengue control?
canonical_answer: Community clean-ups, eliminating breeding sites, public education, targeted larval control, and early case reporting are key measures to prevent and control outbreaks.

title: Emergency signs summary
question_variants: What symptoms need emergency care in dengue?
Signs that I should go to ER for dengue?
canonical_answer: Seek immediate care for severe abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, difficulty breathing, bleeding, fainting, or severe lethargy — these may indicate severe dengue.

title: Antipyretics in dengue
question_variants: Which fever medicines for dengue?
Can I use aspirin for dengue fever?
canonical_answer: Use paracetamol for fever and pain. Avoid aspirin and NSAIDs due to bleeding risk. Follow dosing instructions and consult healthcare providers for children.

title: Test availability locally
question_variants: Are dengue tests widely available?
Where can I get dengue tests?
canonical_answer: Availability varies by location. Contact local clinics or public health services for information on available tests and where to get tested.

title: Post-dengue fatigue
question_variants: Why am I tired after dengue?
How long does fatigue last after dengue?
canonical_answer: Fatigue commonly persists for weeks after dengue. Rest, gradual return to activity, and good nutrition help recovery. Seek medical advice if fatigue is prolonged or worsening.

title: Secondary infections after dengue
question_variants: Can I get other infections after dengue?
Is dengue followed by other illnesses?
canonical_answer: There is no routine expectation of a specific secondary infection after dengue, though individual recovery varies. Seek care for new or worsening symptoms.

title: Bed nets and dengue
question_variants: Do bed nets help prevent dengue?
Are mosquito nets useful for dengue prevention?
canonical_answer: Bed nets protect at night and are useful for infants and those resting during the day, but Aedes mosquitoes bite during the day so combine nets with daytime protection.

title: Pregnancy monitoring with dengue
question_variants: How is dengue monitored during pregnancy?
What special steps for pregnant women with dengue?
canonical_answer: Pregnant people with suspected dengue need clinical monitoring for maternal and fetal well-being. Management decisions should be individualized by clinicians.

title: Cleaning water containers
question_variants: How to clean water storage to stop mosquitoes?
Best practices for water container maintenance?
canonical_answer: Scrub and cover water storage containers, change water regularly, and seal or treat large storage per local guidance to reduce mosquito breeding.

title: Reporting breeding sites
question_variants: How can community report breeding sites?
Can I report mosquito hotspots?
canonical_answer: Many localities have hotlines or online portals to report breeding sites or suspected cases. Contact your local health department for reporting options.

title: Protecting infants from dengue
question_variants: How to protect babies from dengue?
What should parents do to protect infants?
canonical_answer: Protect infants with screened rooms, bed nets for sleeping infants, age-appropriate repellents, and remove nearby breeding sites. Seek pediatric care for any infant illness.

title: Environmental sanitation role
question_variants: Does trash management reduce dengue?
How does environment affect dengue?
canonical_answer: Proper waste management reduces containers that collect water and serve as mosquito breeding sites. Community sanitation and drainage improvements reduce vector habitats.

title: Identifying Aedes breeding sites
question_variants: Where do Aedes mosquitoes breed?
Common breeding sites for dengue mosquitoes?
canonical_answer: Aedes breed in clean, stagnant water in containers such as plant saucers, buckets, discarded tires, and clogged gutters. Regular inspection and removal reduce breeding.

title: When to consult a specialist
question_variants: Do I need a specialist for dengue?
When to see an infectious disease doctor?
canonical_answer: Most dengue patients are managed by general clinicians. Specialists may be involved for severe or complicated cases.

title: School policies for dengue
question_variants: Can schools reopen after dengue cases?
How should schools manage dengue risk?
canonical_answer: School decisions are guided by local public health authorities. Measures include education, eliminating breeding sites on premises, and advising parents to seek care for ill children.

title: Talking to health worker
question_variants: What should I tell the doctor about dengue?
How to report symptoms to clinician?
canonical_answer: Provide onset date, fever pattern, bleeding, vomiting, travel history, and exposure to mosquito areas. Mention pregnancy or chronic illnesses to help clinicians select appropriate tests and care.

title: Vector control community programs
question_variants: What do vector control programs do?
How do health departments control dengue?
canonical_answer: Programs include surveillance, source reduction, larviciding, targeted adult mosquito control, and public education. Community engagement is key to program success.

title: Insecticide treated clothing
question_variants: Does treated clothing prevent dengue?
Can I wear insecticide-treated clothes?
canonical_answer: Insecticide-treated clothing can reduce mosquito bites for people at high risk, but follow product instructions and public health guidance. It complements other protective measures.

title: Vertical transmission of dengue
question_variants: Can dengue pass from mother to baby?
Is vertical transmission of dengue possible?
canonical_answer: Vertical transmission (mother-to-child) is possible but not common. Pregnant people with dengue should be monitored closely; neonatal care may be needed if the infant is affected.

title: Neonatal dengue overview
question_variants: Can newborns get dengue?
Dengue in newborn babies?
canonical_answer: Newborns can be affected via vertical transmission or mosquito bites after birth; symptoms may be non-specific and require pediatric evaluation. Protect infants from mosquito exposure.

title: Cross-reactivity with Zika
question_variants: Do dengue tests react with Zika?
Can dengue test be confused with Zika?
canonical_answer: Serologic tests can show cross-reactivity between dengue and Zika viruses; molecular tests (PCR) and clinical context help distinguish them. Consult laboratory specialists for interpretation.

title: Platelet transfusion in dengue
question_variants: When give platelets in dengue?
Is platelet transfusion needed for dengue?
canonical_answer: Platelet transfusion is not routinely required for low platelets alone; it is considered for significant bleeding or specific clinical scenarios per clinical guidelines.

title: Hemoconcentration and plasma leakage
question_variants: What is plasma leakage in dengue?
How does dengue cause shock?
canonical_answer: Severe dengue can cause plasma leakage leading to hemoconcentration and shock. Clinical monitoring of hematocrit, fluids, and vital signs helps detect and manage this condition.

title: Managing shock in dengue
question_variants: How is shock treated in dengue?
Emergency care for dengue shock?
canonical_answer: Dengue shock is a medical emergency treated with careful IV fluid resuscitation, monitoring of vital signs and urine output, and supportive care in hospital settings.

title: Oral rehydration solutions
question_variants: Is ORS good for dengue?
What fluids should dengue patients drink?
canonical_answer: Oral rehydration solutions help maintain electrolytes and hydration in mild to moderate dehydration. Follow clinician guidance on volume and frequency.

title: Nutrition during recovery
question_variants: What to eat after dengue?
Diet during dengue recovery?
canonical_answer: Eat balanced meals, maintain hydration, and include foods that are easy to digest and nutritionally adequate. Specific diets do not cure dengue but support recovery.

title: Analgesics caution in dengue
question_variants: Are painkillers safe in dengue?
Can I take ibuprofen with dengue?
canonical_answer: Prefer paracetamol for pain/fever. Avoid NSAIDs and aspirin due to bleeding risk. Check with a healthcare provider before taking other medications.

title: When to repeat dengue tests
question_variants: Should dengue tests be repeated?
When to retest for dengue?
canonical_answer: Testing strategy depends on illness day and initial result. Repeat testing may be useful if early tests are negative but suspicion remains; consult clinicians or lab guidance.

title: Community cleanup campaigns
question_variants: How to organize a dengue cleanup?
What is a community larval source reduction?
canonical_answer: Organize regular community clean-ups to remove containers, educate residents, and coordinate with local authorities for sustained vector control.

title: Larvicides use and safety
question_variants: Are larvicides useful for dengue?
Is it safe to treat water with larvicides?
canonical_answer: Larvicides can reduce mosquito larvae in water storage if used per public health guidance. Follow safety instructions and local program recommendations.

title: Community surveillance importance
question_variants: What is dengue surveillance?
Why track dengue cases?
canonical_answer: Surveillance detects increases in cases early, guides response, and helps target vector control efforts. Reporting by clinicians and labs supports surveillance systems.

title: Breteau index explained (general)
question_variants: What is Breteau index?
How measure mosquito breeding index?
canonical_answer: Entomological indices (like Breteau index) measure container-positive households and help quantify vector density; public health programs use these metrics to plan control actions.

title: Gutters and roof water
question_variants: Do gutters breed mosquitoes?
How to maintain gutters to prevent dengue?
canonical_answer: Clogged gutters can hold water and become breeding sites. Regular cleaning and ensuring proper drainage reduce mosquito habitats.

title: Plant saucers and vases
question_variants: Do plant saucers cause dengue?
How to manage water in plant pots?
canonical_answer: Empty or change water in plant saucers regularly or add sand/drainage to prevent standing water. Cover or remove non-essential containers.

title: Discarded tires management
question_variants: Why are tires a problem for dengue?
How to dispose tyres to stop mosquitoes?
canonical_answer: Discarded tires collect rainwater and are ideal breeding sites; proper disposal or recycling and community clean-ups reduce this risk.

title: Water storage safety
question_variants: How to store water safely?
Prevent mosquitoes in water tanks?
canonical_answer: Cover water storage, install tight lids or screens, and clean containers regularly to prevent mosquito breeding in household water storage.

title: Waste management and dengue
question_variants: Does waste collection affect dengue?
Can garbage increase dengue risk?
canonical_answer: Poor waste management increases container habitats. Regular waste collection and disposal reduce breeding sites and dengue risk.

title: Roof gutters and water pooling
question_variants: Can roof water cause dengue?
Fixing roof pooling to prevent mosquitoes?
canonical_answer: Ensure roofs drain properly; fix pooling water and maintain gutters to avoid standing water that serves as mosquito breeding sites.

title: Rainwater harvesting precautions
question_variants: Is rainwater harvesting risky for dengue?
How to protect rainwater systems?
canonical_answer: Design rainwater systems to prevent mosquito entry, cover storage, and maintain systems regularly per public health recommendations.

title: Community education messages
question_variants: What messages reduce dengue?
How to educate community about dengue?
canonical_answer: Simple messages: eliminate standing water, use repellents and screens, seek care for fever, and report suspected cases to local health authorities.

title: Role of schools in prevention
question_variants: How can schools prevent dengue?
School dengue control measures?
canonical_answer: Schools can remove breeding sites on premises, educate students and staff, and coordinate with health authorities during outbreaks.

title: Workplace dengue measures
question_variants: How workplaces reduce dengue risk?
Employer measures for dengue prevention?
canonical_answer: Employers can reduce breeding sites on premises, promote protective behaviors, and facilitate sick leave policies for ill employees.

title: Protecting outdoor workers
question_variants: How to protect outdoor workers from dengue?
Repellents for field workers?
canonical_answer: Provide protective clothing, repellents, rest breaks, and shaded areas; schedule work to reduce peak mosquito exposure where possible.

title: Vector surveillance methods
question_variants: How to monitor mosquito populations?
Tools used for mosquito surveillance?
canonical_answer: Surveillance uses larval surveys, adult mosquito traps, and indices like Breteau index to monitor vector populations and guide interventions.

title: Community mobilization examples
question_variants: How mobilize community for dengue?
Examples of community dengue action?
canonical_answer: Community mobilization includes clean-up days, school programs, local champions, and partnerships with health departments to sustain control efforts.

title: Protecting travellers
question_variants: How to avoid dengue while travelling?
Travelers' protection against dengue?
canonical_answer: Use repellents, protective clothing, check local disease risk, and seek pre-travel health advice; after travel, seek care for fever promptly.

title: Role of clinics in reporting
question_variants: How do clinics report dengue?
Clinic reporting for dengue cases?
canonical_answer: Clinics report suspected and confirmed cases per national guidelines to public health authorities to enable timely response and surveillance.

title: Community vector control partnerships
question_variants: How do communities partner for control?
Building partnerships for dengue control?
canonical_answer: Partnerships among communities, health departments, and NGOs support sustained vector control, education, and outbreak response.

title: Mosquito life cycle basics
question_variants: How long do dengue mosquitoes live?
What is the life cycle of Aedes mosquitoes?
canonical_answer: Aedes mosquitoes develop from eggs to larvae to pupae to adults; lifecycle length depends on temperature and conditions. Removing breeding sites interrupts this cycle.

title: Eggs of Aedes and drought
question_variants: Can Aedes eggs survive dry periods?
Do mosquito eggs survive drought?
canonical_answer: Aedes eggs can survive dry conditions for months and hatch when water returns; consistent source reduction is important to prevent re-emergence.

title: Larvae identification basics
question_variants: How to spot mosquito larvae?
What do mosquito larvae look like?
canonical_answer: Mosquito larvae are small, wriggling organisms in standing water; local vector control programs can assist with identification and control measures.

title: Community-based surveillance examples
question_variants: What is community surveillance?
How can communities help detect dengue?
canonical_answer: Community members can report clusters of fever, breeding sites, or sick individuals to local health authorities to support early detection.

title: Household inspection checklist
question_variants: What to check at home for dengue?
Home checklist to prevent mosquitoes?
canonical_answer: Inspect for standing water in containers, gutters, plant saucers, and water storage; empty, cover, or clean routinely to reduce breeding.

title: Integrated vector management overview
question_variants: What is IVM?
Integrated vector management explained?
canonical_answer: Integrated Vector Management combines environmental management, biological control, chemical control, and community engagement tailored to local contexts for sustainable control.

title: Targeted indoor residual spraying
question_variants: Is indoor spraying effective for dengue?
Use of indoor residual spraying?
canonical_answer: Indoor residual spraying targets resting mosquitoes in houses; its role in dengue programs varies by context and should follow public health guidance.

title: Space spraying during outbreaks
question_variants: When to spray for dengue?
Is fogging effective for dengue outbreaks?
canonical_answer: Space spraying (fogging) can temporarily reduce adult mosquito numbers during outbreaks but should be used with other measures and targeted based on surveillance.

title: Biological control agents
question_variants: Can fish or copepods control mosquitoes?
Biological control for mosquito larvae?
canonical_answer: Some biological agents (larvivorous fish, copepods, Bacillus thuringiensis israelensis) can reduce larvae in certain settings; use as part of integrated programs per guidance.

title: Community risk mapping
question_variants: How map dengue risk?
What is risk mapping for dengue?
canonical_answer: Risk mapping uses case data, vector indices, and environmental factors to identify hotspots and prioritize interventions.

title: Household water management tips
question_variants: How to manage household water to prevent dengue?
Home water safety tips?
canonical_answer: Cover containers, empty standing water, clean storage regularly, and maintain septic and drainage systems to reduce breeding habitats.

title: Role of NGOs in dengue control
question_variants: How NGOs help dengue control?
Non-profits and dengue prevention?
canonical_answer: NGOs support community education, mobilization, and sometimes vector control activities, complementing public health efforts.

title: Public communication during outbreaks
question_variants: How communicate about dengue outbreaks?
Messaging during dengue outbreaks?
canonical_answer: Clear, consistent messages about seeking care, preventing mosquito breeding, and reporting cases help communities respond and reduce panic.

title: Use of mobile apps for reporting
question_variants: Can apps help report dengue?
Mobile tools for dengue reporting?
canonical_answer: Mobile reporting apps can help report breeding sites or suspected cases quickly, supporting surveillance and response when integrated with public health systems.

title: Managing water in construction sites
question_variants: Do construction sites breed mosquitoes?
How to prevent mosquitoes at building sites?
canonical_answer: Construction sites often have containers or depressions that hold water; proper site management and drainage reduce breeding risks.

title: Community volunteer roles
question_variants: How volunteers help in dengue control?
What volunteers do for dengue prevention?
canonical_answer: Volunteers can lead clean-up efforts, educate neighbors, and assist with surveillance, amplifying public health outreach.

title: Dengue in elderly people
question_variants: Is dengue worse in elderly?
How does dengue affect older adults?
canonical_answer: Older adults may have higher risk of complications due to underlying conditions; monitor them closely and seek care for warning signs.

title: Comorbidities and dengue risk
question_variants: Does diabetes affect dengue?
Are people with chronic illness at higher risk?
canonical_answer: Chronic conditions can influence dengue severity and management; clinicians consider comorbidities in monitoring and treatment decisions.

title: Managing dengue in remote areas
question_variants: How treat dengue in remote locations?
Dengue care in rural areas?
canonical_answer: Early recognition, referral pathways, and community-based measures are important; strengthen local capacity for triage and transport to higher care when needed.

title: Laboratory biosafety for dengue
question_variants: How to handle dengue samples safely?
Lab safety for dengue testing?
canonical_answer: Laboratory handling of dengue specimens follows biosafety protocols to protect staff and ensure test quality; follow national lab guidelines.

title: Clinical triage flow
question_variants: How triage dengue patients?
Triage steps for suspected dengue?
canonical_answer: Triage includes assessing warning signs, dehydration, bleeding, vital signs, and ability to tolerate oral intake to determine need for observation or admission.

title: Follow-up after dengue discharge
question_variants: When to follow up after dengue?
Post-discharge care for dengue patients?
canonical_answer: Arrange follow-up to monitor recovery and any delayed complications; advise patients on gradual return to activity and signs prompting re-evaluation.

title: Psychosocial support after dengue
question_variants: Can dengue affect mental health?
Support after dengue illness?
canonical_answer: Recovery can include prolonged fatigue and mood changes; provide reassurance, gradual return to activities, and access to support if needed.

title: Pediatric dosing reminders
question_variants: How dose paracetamol for kids?
Medication dosing in children with dengue?
canonical_answer: Use weight-appropriate dosing for paracetamol and consult pediatric guidelines or a clinician. Avoid NSAIDs and aspirin in children.

title: Community entomology education
question_variants: What to teach about mosquitoes?
Entomology education for communities?
canonical_answer: Teach identification of breeding sites, mosquito behavior, and practical prevention steps such as covering water and cleaning containers.

title: Wastewater and dengue
question_variants: Can sewage cause dengue?
Does wastewater affect mosquito breeding?
canonical_answer: Poor drainage and standing water associated with wastewater can increase breeding habitats; proper sanitation and drainage reduce risk.

title: Emergency transport planning
question_variants: How transport severe dengue patients?
Arranging transport for dengue emergencies?
canonical_answer: Have referral and transport plans for severe cases to reach facilities capable of managing shock and bleeding; coordinate with local health services.

title: Community mapping of breeding sites
question_variants: How map local breeding sites?
Mapping hotspots for mosquitoes?
canonical_answer: Map common container types and hotspots to prioritize interventions and community clean-ups; use simple data collection tools.

title: Role of pharmacists
question_variants: How can pharmacists help dengue control?
Pharmacist role in dengue care?
canonical_answer: Pharmacists advise on safe medication use (avoid NSAIDs), encourage health-seeking for warning signs, and support patient education on symptom monitoring.

title: Clinical documentation tips
question_variants: What to record for dengue patients?
Key notes for clinical dengue records?
canonical_answer: Document symptom onset, warning signs, vitals, fluid intake/output, lab results, and any changes to guide ongoing care and reporting.

title: Home oxygen for dengue
question_variants: Is oxygen helpful at home?
Can I use oxygen for dengue at home?
canonical_answer: Home oxygen is not appropriate for severe respiratory distress; seek urgent medical care if breathing difficulty occurs and oxygen therapy may be provided in hospital as needed.

title: Community monitoring of vector indices
question_variants: How track mosquito density?
Monitoring Aedes populations in community?
canonical_answer: Track larval and adult mosquito indices through regular surveys to assess program impact and guide control efforts.

title: School-based surveillance
question_variants: Can schools track dengue cases?
School surveillance for dengue?
canonical_answer: Schools can monitor absenteeism patterns and report clusters of illness to health authorities to support early detection.

title: Public-private partnerships
question_variants: How can private sector help?
Role of private companies in dengue control?
canonical_answer: Private sector can support community campaigns, funding, and workplace prevention measures, partnering with public health programs.

title: Safe disposal of containers
question_variants: How dispose containers safely?
Trash handling to prevent mosquitoes?
canonical_answer: Remove or puncture discarded containers, ensure proper waste collection, and recycle tires and plastics to eliminate breeding sites.

title: Use of personal protective equipment
question_variants: Do PPE work for dengue prevention?
Should health workers wear PPE for dengue?
canonical_answer: Standard precautions protect health workers; PPE use is guided by clinical and lab procedures. For general prevention, protective clothing and repellents are recommended.

title: Entomological surveillance indicators
question_variants: What are common vector indicators?
How measure mosquito populations?
canonical_answer: Common indicators include container index, house index, and Breteau index; programs use these to gauge vector presence and trends.

title: Tailored messaging for high-risk groups
question_variants: How target messages?
Messaging for pregnant women about dengue?
canonical_answer: Tailor messages to risk groups (pregnant people, children, elderly) with relevant prevention and care information and encourage timely health-seeking.

title: Case investigation basics
